subsubsection.title: Definition of the Definite Integral
subsubsection.definition: Let f be a function defined for a\leq x\leq b, and divide [a,b] into n subintervals of width \Delta x = \dfrac{b-a}{n}. Let a=x_0,x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_{n-1},x_n=b be the endpoints of these subintervals, and let x_i^* be any sample points in these subintervals, so that x_i^* lies in the ith subinterval [x_{i-1},x_i]. Then, the definite integral of f from a to b is given by \ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx = \sum_{n=1}^\infty f(x_i^*)\Delta x provided that this limit exists and gives the same value for all possible choices of sample points. If it does exist, we say that f is integrable on [a,b]. The sum \ds \sum_{n=1}^\infty f(x_i^*)\Delta x is called a Riemann sum.

assemblage.title: Terminology
assemblage.p:
Given the definite integral \ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx, we have some terminology:
a is called the lower bound/lower limit of integration
b is called the upper bound/upper limit of integration
\ds \int is called an integral sign
We use dx to denote an infinitesimal change in x

theorem.statement: If f is continuous on [a,b], or if f has a finite number of discontinuities, then f is integrable on [a,b].
If f is integrable on [a,b], then \ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx = \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i)\Delta x where \Delta x = \dfrac{b-a}{n} and x_i = a + i\Delta x

assemblage.title: Interpretation of the Integral
assemblage.p:
The definite integral \ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx can be interpreted as
The total area between f(x) and the x-axis if f(x)\geq 0 on [a,b]
The net area between f(x) and the x-axis if f(x)\geq 0 and f(x) < 0 on [a,b]

subsubsection.title: The Midpoint Rule
subsubsection.introduction: Instead of choosing our sample points to be left or right endpoints, we can choose any point inside the subinterval; a standout is the midpoint of the interval.

definition.title: Midpoint Rule
definition.p: \ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx \approx \sum_{i=1}^n f(\overline{x_i})\Delta x where \Delta x = \dfrac{b-a}{n} and \overline{x_i} = \dfrac{x_{i-1}+x_i}{2} is the midpoint of the interval [x_{i-1},x_i].

subsubsection.title: Properties of the Definite Integral
subsubsection.introduction: The following are useful properties when working with the definite integral:

theorem.title: Properties of the Definite Integral
theorem.statement:
Let f,g be continuous functions on [a,b]. Let c be a constant. Then,
\ds \int_a^b f(x)\,dx = -\int_b^a f(x)\, dx
\ds \int_a^a f(x)\,dx = 0
\ds \int_a^b c\, dx = c(b-a)
\ds \int_a^b [f(x)\pm g(x)]\,dx = \int_a^b f(x)\,dx\pm \int_a^b g(x)\,dx
\int_a^b cf(x)\,dx = c\int_a^b f(x)\,dx
\ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx = \int_a^d f(x)\, dx + \int_d^b f(x)\, dx, for some a \lt d \lt b
